ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Some of the assignments (recovery plan analysis, op-ed) were very useful and helpful. But a couple of the assignments (write a page about what you've learned, and the pocket guide) were less helpful towards my learning and more just felt like busy work. I would not include those assignments in future courses or see if they could be modified to be made more learning-focused.

There was no participatory application of the frameworks in class. It was all theoretical and up in the air. The class would have benefited from applying the framework to made up or real cases in class as a group exercise for practice. The class would have also benefited from having more discussion - the way the last class went.I felt that the framework was often presented dogmatically. It was this way or no way, which makes me reluctant to embrace it. Dr. Clark is a wonderful and friendly person, but I think her teaching style did not facilitate discussion or engender participation.

Although, Dr. Clark is incredibly knowledge and I found our discussions outside of class useful professionally and personally, but classroom teaching style made it hard to engage in the material. I felt that discussion was stifled instead of facilitated.

The course was well designed and provided very useful conservation tools to students who will engage inacademically or professionally in research and conservation projects. The instructor touched-base critical aspects and factors which are affecting species survival worldwide, including climate change, land tenure and use, and other anthropogenic-based actions. Students worked on individual and group species projects which made the class very useful as students could manipulate data to predict the current and future distribution of their species. This exercise was very important for students, mostly those who are heading to their professional endeavors on species conservation in the field.

The readings were great but perhaps a better explanation of them from the Professor versus the class discussion.Also, the start of of the class was slower with way too many assignments towards the end. It would be better if the assignments were well paced with each class.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Working in teams to figure out the policy sciences, and the field trip to Jackson Hole, WY.
Marian Vernon.The field trip to Jackson was exceptional. I felt like things began to solidify during that shape and I finally started to have some idea of what we were talking about.
discussion topics that are not traditionally discussed in most other classes. Encouraged students to think outside of the box.

The field trip was a great opportunity to meet people and get a sense of the conservation landscape in Jackson, WY.Prof. Clark was available and accessible outside of class and genuinely cares about her students.The written assignments in the course were excellent. More clarity at the beginning of the semester in terms of what these assignments would be and where they were due would be helpful.
it is a comprehensive course that included more that ecological concepts
The readings and introduction to the policy process.

Over the summer, I will be assessing great ape distribution and abundance along with their habitat as well as the impact anthropogenic actions on their population shaping. This course has provided me with skills, knowledge and tools which will be used in carrying this project scientifically and professionally.

The field trip was definitely the best part of the course. It was useful to see the different ways thatorganizations approach human-wildlife conflict on the ground. I think the course material is generally useful, but have some qualifications of how it is expressed (see below).
Case studies really helped to make complex concepts more clear

Prof. Susan Clark is the best aspect of this course! She is highly knowledgeable and is an amazing human being. She is great outside class and is supportive of discussions beyond what is taught in class.The content of the class is great too

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Lectures.

The workload in this class was totally unbalanced. There was nothing due before break and then a stack of work required after it. Assignments were worthwhile, but not organized in a manner that allowed progressive learning. The pocket guide should have been required almost immediately to help solidify conceptual understanding of the material, instead of at the end, by which time it was nearly pointless.The syllabus offered no indication of the deliverables, dates, or expectations.

Their was great improvement as the semester progressed on being clear about expected deliverable but it was frustrating for most of the semester as it was unclear what was expected and when. It would also be helpful to have more specific outline of the semester so that we could clearly see where we are going and where we have been. The weekly letters are helpful but it would be nice to know that things were planned a little further in advance. I understand the need to have a flexible semester outline but a little more structure would be nice.

Class time itself would benefit from more discussion, less lecture, and more clear learning objectives for each class.Readings and assignments generally were often not discussed in class, so students stopped preparing. I think it would be more effective to select a smaller number of readings and to provide more structure and opportunity for class discussion.

More structure or discussions facilitated by students would have helped. I think the most useful part of the functional accounting framework is application which we had little exposure too. Casestudies would have been useful to think through the process.

The course was well designed, the content was consistent and it was taught in a way that I leaned a lot from it, and to be used in my conservation projects. I didn't see any needed improvement in the course.

The seminar part of the course was not well organized, often repetitive, and did not enhance understanding of the readings. This course is too repetitive of the fall course and did not add much new material beyond it. The policy process book should have been addressed in the first two or three weeks of class (either the fall course is a prerequisite or students must read the book in the first two weeks of class) and then the class should move on, instead of rehashing the book over the entire semester. The powerpoints were also repetitive - I think we saw the same slide with the eight values at least four times.The outside assignments were useful but could have been spaced differently. The handbook should have been done before spring break.Also, the readings start to seem repetitive after a while (you can only read the phrase 'we introduce a multi-disciplinary framework' so many times). Papers by other authors should be used more often (Brunner, for example).
Structure within and between lectures and more integration between readings, assignments, and lectures
A better clarification of exercises and deliverables.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A. This would have been a valuable addition.
were none
Yes, every section of the course was sanctioned by a lab which enabled students to gain both theoretic and practical skills from the class.

This course could use a discussion section with the TA , or more regularly scheduled office hours with the TA, who is very good at using the policy sciences framework in a way that students understand.
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It doesn't.

this class is needed to help people who are looking at conservation issues to see the larger picture. I don't know if professor Clark would ever be up for co-teaching but I would love to see her teach a required course like science to solutions

I am approaching conservation from a social science perspectives. This course helped me contextualize this and made me realize that social science truly is important to the field. I can now think through who different stakeholders are and pinpoint where the weakness in the conservation process is.

I didn't have any previous academic biological background rather than professional skills. Thus, the course provided me with an academic layer of conservation-science,understanding principles and how science can be carefully applied in conservation projects; skills which I lacked in my previous professional activities.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I thought I was going to learn policy skills, collaboration techniques and conservation tools, all of which would have been extremely valuable in my course of study. I didn't.I also took it to add a layer of geographic diversity to my studies, outside of the New England region. I did get to do that.
I took professor Clark's course in the fall and love it.

I was interested in the interdisciplinary nature of the course. I have found true interdisciplinary courses to be lacking at FES and was hoping this course would help integrate my learning from other classes.
I am interesting in focusing my career on integrative conservation
I wanted to expose myself to the field of conservation and though this would be a great introduction.

I was interested in learning how science can be applied in conservation projects and the gap between science and its implementation. I was also interested in species conservation on landscapes composed of different habitats with different structures of governance and management, such as, species inhabiting protected and non-protected areas; especially, how conservation science results can be used in conservation governance to move conservation regulations for these species preservation.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes and no, I learned some but I also was hoping to feel more of a greater understanding by the end of the course.

No. The class did a terrible job of teaching the fundamentals before jumping into more abstract components. It is generally assumed that you have taken Clark's earlier class, or perfectly absorbed her book. If either of these are untrue, you're sunk. An organized TA-led section, or perhaps just a few of them, would have gone a long way towards clarifying what was happening in that class.There were very few opportunities for genuinely engagement or debate. Mostly the instructor offered her viewas fact and left it there. That said, outside of class, Clark is extremely approachable and receptive. She pushes you to take your thought process a step further and consider alternatives you had not thought of. I wish the class were taught hanging out with her in a coffee shop.
fell a bit shy of my expectations but it is so different from other classes that it is important to help us see issues in a different way.
To be honest, I think I need more time and distance from the class to have a real sense of how the course changed my thinking.
Not really.

This class was above my expectation, the topic that are taught have a great utility, and they come apart of the stander conservation classes. at the end, this class give a better approach to what a real conservation programs have to be.
Yes! I was very satisfied with the skills and knowledge I gained from this class.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was helpful to talk through some of the concepts of the course with others to clarify our own understandings of the materials.
Thank God for my group partner. Almost everything I learned this semester, I learned from them, in spite of the class.
I think group (in this case partner) work is a great learning opportunity and I appreciated that it was emphasized in this course.I would love to see more group work at FES.
This class encourage discussion and sharing ideas. Then, work on groups became in a good way about debating ideas and defending them.

The group work requires skills in GIS and Statistics, in addition to the overall conservation skills and knowledge. The group was composed of students from different background where every one learned from each one.
This course was at times challenging conceptually and having someone to throw ideas around with was invaluable

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Spend the time getting to know Susan and talkingwith her during office hours. And get help /talk to the TF if you are really struggling.
Don't do it. It's frustrating and pointless. Read the Policy Process in your own time and spare yourself the trouble.
This class is for students that are comfortable with limited instruction. That element can be challenging to overcome but the benefits are you challenge your preconceived ideas and epistemology.

I would only recommend this course to students who are able to go on the field trip. I think that class time itself was not used effectively enough to convey ideas clearly. For students who can't attend the field trip, I would recommend reading Susan's book, "The Policy Process" and not taking the course.More generally, I would recommend that the field trip be a required component of the course so that the curriculum could integrate the trip more fully.

This class present a different perspective about conservation. Additionally, it is a good place to debate about conservation's ideas and programs in US, but also give an opportunity to look compare with international conservation programs.
The course fits for both students in Environmental management and in Forestry. My suggestion would be "it is a must take".
